Literature Review: Macrophages and dendritic cells are crucial components of the tumor microenvironment, playing significant roles in cancer progression and response to treatment. The unique biology of these cells, including their ability to shape the tumor microenvironment and instruct T cell-mediated tumor cell killing, makes them attractive targets for cancer immunotherapy. Recent advances in understanding the cellular identity, molecular diversity, and spatial organization of mononuclear phagocytes (MNPs) in tumors have expanded the possibilities for therapeutic modulation. This review aims to summarize the current knowledge on MNP biology in the antitumor immune response and discuss the importance of tailoring therapeutic strategies to incorporate these new insights into cancer treatment design.
